[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: chan_size] [Resource Exhaustion] Can a malicious configuration file set chan_size to an extremely large value (e.g., usize::MAX) causing memory exhaustion when the async logging channel is initialized, potentially crashing validator nodes and causing loss of liveness? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: chan_size] [Integer Overflow] Does the chan_size field have upper bounds validation, or can setting it to a value near usize::MAX cause integer overflow when calculating buffer allocations in the logging system? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: chan_size] [DoS via Zero Value] Can chan_size be set to 0, causing the logging channel to have zero capacity and potentially deadlocking the logging subsystem when messages are queued? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: level] [Information Disclosure] Can an attacker modify the configuration to set level to Level::Trace or Level::Debug in production, causing sensitive validator state, private keys, or transaction details to be logged and exposed through telemetry? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: enable_backtrace] [Resource Exhaustion] If enable_backtrace is set to true with high-frequency error logging, can this cause excessive CPU usage from constant backtrace generation, degrading validator performance during consensus? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: is_async] [Consensus Timing] If is_async is set to false, forcing synchronous logging, can this introduce blocking I/O operations that delay consensus message processing and cause timeout-based liveness failures? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: enable_telemetry_remote_log] [Information Disclosure] When enable_telemetry_remote_log is true, what validation exists to ensure telemetry endpoints are trusted, or can an attacker redirect logs to a malicious server to exfiltrate validator operational data? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: enable_telemetry_flush] [Data Loss] If enable_telemetry_flush is set to false, can critical error logs be lost during unexpected validator crashes, making post-incident forensics impossible and hiding evidence of attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: telemetry_level] [Information Disclosure] Can telemetry_level be misconfigured to send verbose logs (Level::Trace) to remote telemetry, exposing sensitive internal state to external monitoring services? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Struct: LoggerConfig, Field: tokio_console_port] [Port Conflict] Can setting tokio_console_port to a port already in use by critical services (e.g., consensus port, API port) cause port binding conflicts that prevent the validator from starting? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: Default::default()] [Hardcoded Values] Does the default chan_size value of CHANNEL_SIZE have adequate capacity for high-throughput validators, or can default configuration cause message drops during transaction bursts? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: Default::default()] [Security Defaults] Is the default enable_backtrace value of false appropriate, or does this reduce debuggability when investigating consensus failures or Byzantine validator attacks? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: Default::default()] [Telemetry Defaults] Does the default enable_telemetry_remote_log value of true pose privacy risks by enabling remote logging without explicit operator consent in default configurations? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: Default::default()] [Debug Exposure] Is the default tokio_console_port value of None secure, or should there be additional warnings when operators manually enable tokio console on production validators? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: disable_tokio_console()] [State Consistency] If disable_tokio_console() is called while the tokio console is already running, can this cause resource leaks or dangling listeners that keep the port occupied? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: disable_tokio_console()] [Race Condition] Can concurrent calls to disable_tokio_console() and randomize_ports() create race conditions where tokio_console_port oscillates between Some and None, causing undefined behavior? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: randomize_ports()] [Port Collision] Does utils::get_available_port() implement proper port conflict detection, or can it assign a port that becomes occupied before tokio console starts, causing startup failures? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: randomize_ports()] [Port Range] Can utils::get_available_port() return privileged ports (<1024) requiring root access, causing permission denied errors when non-root validators attempt to start? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: randomize_ports()] [Determinism] Does randomize_ports() affect validator determinism, or can different port assignments across validators cause observable behavioral differences in distributed testing? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: randomize_ports()] [Resource Exhaustion] If randomize_ports() is called repeatedly in a loop, can it exhaust available ports on the system, causing denial of service for other network services? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: sanitize()] [Incomplete Validation] Does sanitize() validate all LoggerConfig fields, or are chan_size, level, and telemetry settings left unchecked, allowing dangerous configurations to pass validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: sanitize()] [Tokio Console Check] In the tokio console validation logic, can an attacker bypass the feature flag check by manipulating environment variables or build flags after compilation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/logger_config.rs] [Function: sanitize(), Lines: 86-92] [Validation Gap] Does the inverse check '!is_tokio_console_enabled() && tokio_console_port.is_some()' properly handle the case where the feature is disabled but a port is legitimately reserved for future use? (Low)
